Yes, Taipei is a city that is becoming increasingly disability-friendly, and there are several landmarks and attractions to visit. Here are some of them:

1. National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall: The memorial hall is fully accessible, with ramps and elevators throughout the building. There are also accessible restrooms and designated parking spots.

2. Taipei Fine Arts Museum: The museum has wheelchair ramps and elevators, as well as accessible restrooms and seating. The museum offers guided tours for individuals with visual or hearing impairments upon request.

3. Taipei Zoo: The zoo has accessible pathways and ramps, as well as wheelchair rentals and accessible restrooms. Some of the animal exhibits have special viewing areas for individuals in wheelchairs.

4. Taipei City Hall: Taipei City Hall is fully accessible, with ramps and elevators throughout the building. There are also accessible restrooms and designated parking spots.

5. Beitou Hot Springs: Beitou Hot Springs has several hot spring resorts that are wheelchair accessible, and some of the bathhouses have wheelchair-accessible tubs.

Overall, Taipei is a city that is making efforts to improve accessibility, and many of the city's landmarks and attractions are becoming increasingly disability-friendly.
